item.title: Idea generation
item.description:
Ideas

Limitations

  • Platform - mobile phone
  • Use touch gesture
  • Use pixels as indicator

Force-touch - hold to call favorite

When user force touch over a certain threshold on the Phone icon the user is given the option to call a favorite contact without having to go through the contact book.

Multi-touch swipe - skip X pages

Depending on amount of fingers touching the screen when swiping skip X amount of pages. E.g. when flicking through the app pages, instead of swiping three times to go from page 1 to page 3, swipe with two fingers to jump forward two pages instead.

Swipe gesture on the “Home button”

Considering that the “home button” now day seem to be smarter than just a regular button (e.g. finger recognition) we wondered if it would be possible to some how detect gestures on it.

How could interacting using gestures on this button rather than the screen aid in everyday actions on the phone?

Interactive billboards

What would happen if public billboards were more like gigantic interactive screens?

How would it handle multiple users?

Would it make people take more notice to and engage more in the message on the billboard (e.g. even if it were a commercial for toothbrushes).

Pinching for overview

Similar to how it’s used on OSX give the user a overview screen of all the active applications; doing this on the phone could as an example present the available pages on the home screen of the phone for faster movement.

Misc ideas

  • Is there any reason for not interacting using the foot more?

Selected idea - Fast scroll / filter scroll.

After a bit more discussions and consulting with the teacher we ended up with a combination of some ideas that we evolved into our current idea. We aim to create something that could be used in context of social media, news site and other sites that are based on articles/posts.

The idea is to allow the user to do fast scroll / filter scroll to quickly skip articles in the article feed based on some search criteria.

In order to do this we split the screen into multiple areas. One area functions like normal and allow the user to scroll normally, the other area(s) act as zones that react on swipe up/down and react by searching for next/previous post using the selected search criteria.

The idea is to allow the user to for example skip posts in social media to jump to next post for a certain friend, page or group without having to scroll forever.

We also have some extra ideas with using force-touch to scroll within post comments that we’re considering trying.

item.title: Module3 introduction
item.description:
Today module 3 was presented to us. The keyword is ‘Nuance’ and as far as I interpreted it, it’s abut expressiveness and flow in the interaction. To simplify step based interactions into something much more fluid and natural feeling.

Material / requirements for the module is touch and pixels. Target device can be anything phone, tablet, billboard, printer, something that don’t exist yet.

Lecture

Skillful coping

  • To keep up with a situation.
  • Things seem to “fall into place”.
  • We do just the right thing at the right moment.
  • Seem to flow, don’t need to know about the how.

Ideas

  • Start with something with limited nuance.
  • Look for interactions that involve repeated steps, or selection from a menu menu option.
  • See if you can “collapse” it down into a single expressive action.

Material quality

  • Maybe pixels can be used and feed-forward in a abstract non-symbolic way?
  • How could touch be used more for continuous fluid interaction rather than poking fake buttons?

User stories

Example 1

MAH printer system requires multiple steps in order to print, even in the case where the user want’s to print everything, or the there’s only one thing in the queue. It would be desirable if the user could in a easy manner skip this friction in the interaction and create a flow, making the experience better and give the user more expressiveness in it’s way of commanding the printer.

Notes

Kattegat contains a good collection of touch related samples.

Kattegat

Install:

$ npm install -g generator-kattegat

Create project:

$ yo kattegat

Start:

$ npm start [tunnel]

item.title: Presentation of Module2
item.description:
We meet up in the morning to test so everything worked, of course it didn’t. One important wire was broken and needed replacement and one vibrator wire needed to be re-attached.

After we confirmed everything as working we went to the presentation.

Presentation

While a bit nervous the presentation went fine. They seemed to think it was an interesting concept. Nothing really negative to say about it. They suggested taking a step back from our context and see in what other areas/context the idea could be used - to explore outside the context.

They seemed to like the idea of giving one of the user all the control (touch) while the other loosing the control (user with vibrator) having to rely on the other user.

item.title: 2016-09-28: Status update
item.description:
Today we’ve worked some more on the prototype.

  • We attached the sensors and vibrators to the two cloth-pieces. (see attached image)
  • Added communication code using the Wire Library for communication between the two Arduino devices.
  • Fixed battery adaptors for the Arduinos.

Notes

  • Social akwardness
  • Positive/negative feelings subjective - e.g. rollercoaster’s amount of scary-fun depends on the user.
  • Self sacrifice
  • Control frame - give user more control (more control good/bad? more control of other good/bad?)
  • Positive: Breaking ice
  • Negative: Making yourself center of attention / making fool of yoursef.

Issues:

  • Having on Arduino power both of the devices seemed to draw too much current so we decided on using batteries for each device - this should hopefully fix the issue as it’s been tested before that one Arduino indeed can power all five vibrators.
  • We’ve been having issues with the lab wires send with the Arduinos - they seem to either be broken from beginning or breaking too easy. We’ve had to replace a few.

Resolved:

  • It seems the touch will be fine siting on the clothes as far as we’ve tested. No false positives.

item.title: Module2 kick-off
item.description:
Was feeling a bit better today so we meet up to talk about the project and do some initial plan for how we were going to work.

We decided on going with “Social Awkwardness”. Being in a environment when you don’t know what to talk about or how to get some connection to the other people there. Designing something to break the ice through self-sacrifice.

We had a bit of brain storming and came up with a few ideas:

  • Go away jeans - detect when offender try to touch users ass and react to it
  • Clapping glove - a glove that creates a synthesized clapping sound when user claps to exaggerate the clapping.
  • Nice comb - complements you while you’re combing your self
  • A dance suit that that with touch and vibration make the user do the macarena dance. <- This is the one we picked

Dance suit thingy

Should have vibrators and some way to feel touch at the same area as the vibrator.

Notes from leture

I2C physical limit ~40m

  • Technology as a mean of expression
  • Body as a mean for communication
  • Interaction as expressive communication
  • Conductive paint as a way to interract
  • Use of skin touching skin (see attached image).

item.title: Module 1 final thoughts
item.description:
Yesterday was the presentation. We meet up an hour before to sync and it was discovered that there was some issues in the prototype. Apparently something had changed in the data that we hadn’t taken into consideration (a registered device without any discovered devices). After fixing this we had a small sync and some coffee. After that it was time for presentation.

Presentation

While it seemed hard to understand our concept at first, I felt that the audience grasped somewhat in the end what we tried to explore. I guess that we had not found a good way of describing our prototype or the findings. Our concept was a bit abstract and on a meta level where we were more focusing on the idea of space.

We had some critique on the concepts use of bluetooth which I can in hindsight understand, as we focused more on exploring space and how things are interpreted.

Things to consider for the future

  • How do we present the findings?

item.title: 2016-09-15: Update
item.description:
What was done yesterday.

We added a new background again to see if this could take us in the direction we wanted to go with the experience. To some extent it felt closer to the initial idea.

After the rewriting of rendering to use DOM/CSS instead of JS canvas there were further enhancements made today so the object resize as the background is “zoomed”, thus creating a feeling of depth.

Issues

After trying with real data from the teachers firebase account it became clear that there might be some performance issues when rendering on a phone.

I’ve done some small optimization but nothing that gives that needed boost.. the best option so far is to put a cap on amount of found devices to render.

What was done today

Result so far:

2D vs 3D space:

Current status

Still a bit slow on mobile unfortunatelly, but good enough for demonstation I guess. We changed from infite animation to active on click/tap. When user interact we either go from 2D to 3D or 3D to 2D depending on current state.

item.title: 2016-09-14: Status update
item.description:
What happened yesterday:

Up until now we have tried to use the canvas objec together with javascript in order to draw the devices. During the day an idea to use CSS instead was formed and was later concived. The result so far looks promising and so far seem to help make the code a bit cleaner and easier to maintain.

The code used to fake found bt devices have also been updated, modularized and moved to it’s own javascript file (btdevice.js). This made the main code much cleaner and easier to get an overview of.

We tried changing the background image to one with a checker pattern to see how the perception changed. The feeling for the new background is positive and seem to give the viewer a better feeling of perspective.

With the newly changed code to use CSS for graphics it was also changed so the background also used CSS and a small test to animate the background was added.

Today:

We added a new background with a centered grid instead to experiment how that would change the perception of depth.

Today I worked some on the coding, try to get a simple version of the idea up and running using HTML5 Canvas and Javascript. Currently there’s some issues with scaling making things look aliased.

It’s currently using manually added fake data from firebase as input.

The idea thus far seem to be that a listening device is represented as a ‘circle’. The size of this ‘circle’ is determined by the amount of found devices. We probablt will need to add some form of scale factor determined from averaging the total found devices between all listeners.

Position and possible animation is not decided on yet.

item.title: 2016-09-07 - Project Presentation: Module 1
item.description:
Project Description

from Fredrik

In the 2D-illustration the space is created between the objects ”balls”. However the idea of the balls are dependent on the viewers perspective and relation to its surrounding. If you don’t have any relation to a object you will compare it to similar objects.

The balls can be viewed upon two ways. That the balls are the same size and they will seam to be more or less distant from the viewers point of view. i.e.a relation in depth. Or that the balls have different sizes and only relate to one and other.

The grid in the backgrund will enhance the feeling of depth and give the viewer a better idea of the balls relation to the space. This because the backgrund will work as a object itself.

In our project the each ball and color can represent a specific devise and the size by the collected amount of bluetooth signals.

time, direction, …
